text: Footnote: The model used in the previous plot, developed with @CCES data by @Anthony_Rentsch, effectively combines both past demographics and intent to vote questions cc @b_schaffner -30-
author: MysteryPollster

text: The main point: Even at 3pm eastern on Election Day, there is much about voter turnout we still don’t know, and many theories for how polls might miss. We will know much more in just a few hours.
author: MysteryPollster

text: So *what if both are true?* What if we're seeing an historically high, inherently younger turnout with disproportionately heavier voting - regardless of past history - among those who favor Democrats? How high up this plot  might the turnout effect go?
author: MysteryPollster

text: Second, simple intent-to-vote questions asked this year show that Dems do best when pollsters narrow their samples to those who say they have already voted or are certain to vote
author: MysteryPollster

text: The chart also implies what pollsters and data gurus have been telling us for the last several election cycles, that a *typical* midterm election turnout is better for Republicans
author: MysteryPollster

text: First, the typical *demographics* of voting indicate that an exceptionally high turnout should mean a stronger Democratic party performance, since typical non-voters tend to be younger, as this @adam_bonica chart shows
author: MysteryPollster

text: But as we ponder what we still don't know about what's happening right now, there's one seemingly contradictory pattern in what surveys are telling us about the relationship between turnout and congressional vote...
author: MysteryPollster

text: As such, no two pollsters selects or models "likely voters" in exactly the same way, and a lot of the poll-to-poll variation, especially in a typically-lower-turnout midterm, comes from differences in these techniques and models
author: MysteryPollster

text: Pollsters have made much progress since with voter files, but same bottom line: Poll questions are good at telling us which candidates our respondents prefer, but bad at predicting which respondents will vote and the overall level of turnout
author: MysteryPollster

text:
Another trip down memory lane prompts a different thought on turnout and likely voters Fourteen years ago, I reviewed how pollsters selected "likely voters" https://www.mysterypollster.com/main/2004/09/how_do_pollster_1.html … 
[Thread]
author: MysteryPollster

text:
This piece from @Catalist_US's @yghitza makes the point even more powerfully, especially on the share of voters with college degrees. Even looking backward, estimates of who voted vary widely, and exit polls appear far off the mark. 
https://medium.com/@yghitza_48326/what-happened-next-tuesday-e4e6637a4b81 … 
-30-
author: MysteryPollster

text:
Finally, for the "who voted" part, be careful on that too. NPR's @asmamk has a really nice summary on that point, part of a longer piece worth reading on the exit poll:
https://www.npr.org/2018/11/05/662946236/how-to-make-sense-of-exit-polls-on-election-night … And…
author: MysteryPollster

text: As for what exit polls can tell you about "why" people voted the way they did, here’s some worthy caution from @BrendanNyhan
author: MysteryPollster

text: And one of the networks paying for the exit poll is telling its reporters to "embrace not knowing". Good idea!
author: MysteryPollster

text: My advice: The best way to stay on top of who's going to win is to watch the @UpshotNYT estimates as the vote is counted, needle and all.
author: MysteryPollster

text: Also, the ABC-CBS-CNN-NBC "exit" polls now consist of a much larger portion of pre-election polling (to gauge early voting) than ever before…
author: MysteryPollster

text: To wit: If you think there's some secret stash of inside data showing who's *really* winning what, think again. Even at or just after poll closing, exit polls won't tell you more (or with any greater certainty) than pre-election polls are telling you right now
author: MysteryPollster
